The development of efficient catalysts for the electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) has emerged as a primary focus in contemporary research. In this study, a series of single-atom catalysts are constructed by doping Ru, Rh, and Pd into C x N3 (x = 7, 10, 13, 19), denoted as M-C x N3. Density functional theory (DFT) methods are employed to systematically investigate the CO2RR catalytic activity and mechanism on M-C x N3. The catalysts are found to exhibit thermodynamic, electrochemical, and dynamic stability, as evidenced by formation energy calculations, dissolution potential assessments, and first principles molecular dynamics simulations. Gibbs free energy calculations reveal that Ru-C x N3 demonstrates exceptional catalytic selectivity towards HCOOH production, with optimal catalytic activity observed at low limiting potentials (x = 7: –0.36 V, x = 10: –0.33 V, x = 13: –0.30 V, and x = 19: –0.18 V). Furthermore, Ru-C x N3 effectively suppresses the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Linear relationships between the Gibbs free energy change of the key intermediate *OCHO and the catalyst d band center, as well as the integration crystal orbital Hamiltonian population (ICOHP), indicate that Ru doping and higher C/N-ratios in C x N3 enhance catalytic performance for CO2RR. This computational study provides comprehensive guidance and insights for the experimental synthesis and exploration of CO2RR electrocatalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Single-atom catalyst Carbon nitride materials Density functional theory Carbon dioxide reduction reaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The excessive exploitation and utilization of fossil fuels have resulted in substantial carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, disrupting the carbon cycle and precipitating a global climate crisis [1–5]. The direct conversion of CO2 into value-added chemicals and fuels through renewable electricity is considered an environmentally favorable approach for establishing a carbon-neutral society [6–8]. However, the stable C = O bonding (750 kJ mol−1) and the high activation barrier required to break the symmetrical linear structure render the electrocatalytic CO2RR process challenging [9,10]. Moreover, CO2RR is typically accompanied by a competitive HER, involving multi-electron/proton transfer steps and generating numerous reaction intermediates, which results in low efficiency and selectivity of CO2RR [11]. Consequently, the utilization of catalysts is proposed as an effective strategy to address these issues. In recent years, Cu-based catalysts have been the focus of research and application in catalyzing CO2RR due to their unique capacity to produce various hydrocarbons or organic oxygenates, such as methane (CH4), ethane (C2H4), methanol (CH3OH), and ethanal (CH3CHO). However, problems such as low selectivity and high over-potential significantly limit their further application. [5,12–19]. Therefore, there is a pressing need for high-performance catalysts with excellent product selectivity and high Faraday efficiency that can accelerate the CO2RR process at low over-potential to improve the energy efficiency of CO2RR. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have recently garnered increasing attention and study due to their unique electronic structure, 100 % atomic utilization, and excellent catalytic performance in the field of electrocatalysis [20–23]. The substrates of SACs play a crucial role in modulating catalytic properties. Various materials, including graphene [24], metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) [25], boron nitride (BN) [26], and carbon nitrides (C x N y ) [27–29] have been reported to exhibit different catalytic activity and selectivity in CO2RR when loaded with a single metal atom to form SACs. Carbon nitrides, particularly C x N y , a polymeric semiconductor with a moderate bandgap and a series of unique electronic and chemical properties, have been extensively studied as substrates for CO2RR catalysis by SACs [30]. Commonly studied carbon nitrides materials include g-C3N4, C2N, and C3N , which have been extensively investigated both experimentally and theoretically. For example, Yang et al. have reported catalyst that loads a single Cu atom into g-C3N4 substrate for efficient CH4 production from CO2RR, achieving the highest CH4 Faraday efficiency of 49.04 % [31]. Hasson et al. have found that a single Zr atom doped into a C2N substrate exhibits better catalytic performance on CO2RR than double or triple Zr atoms doped by means of density functional theory (DFT) methods [32]. Similarly, Zhang et al. have found that single Cu, Co, Fe, and Mn atoms embedded into C3 N for catalyzing CO2RR exhibited good performance with promising application prospects [33]. These studies have shown that doping a single metal atom into C x N y to serve as the active site alters the material property from semiconducting to metallic, resulting in a more favorable electronic structure and thus enhancing electrocatalytic performance. Regarding C x N y with high C/N-ratios, such as C7N3, C10N3, C1 3N3, and C19N3, these materials are predicted to be promising candidates for high-performance electronic devices and energy conversion applications. Moreover, C x N3 (x = 7, 10, 13, 19) have been verified to be energetically, dynamically, and mechanically stable, indicating their experimental feasibility [34]. Furthermore, their porous geometric constructions facilitate the convenient doping of metal atoms to serve as active sites. Consequently, it is hypothesized that single metal atoms doped into C x N3 may exhibit significant electrocatalytic activity. However, comprehensive studies on the catalytic ability of such high C/N-ratio C x N y and the mechanisms of catalyzing CO2RR are currently lacking. In this investigation, a series of catalysts have been constructed by doping single metal atoms of Ruthenium (Ru), Rhodium (Rh), and Palladium (Pd) into C x N3 (x = 7, 10, 13, 19), designated as M-C x N3. The reason for choosing these three group Ⅷ metals is because they exhibit good CO2RR activity in forming SACs in previous works [35–40]. The catalytic performance of these materials has been systematically examined using DFT methods. Initially, the formation energy and dissolution potential of these catalysts were calculated to assess their thermodynamic and electrochemical stability. Subsequently, the adsorption and activation behavior of CO2 on the catalyst active sites were explored, as the disruption of the robust symmetrical linear structure of the CO2 molecule is crucial for catalyzing the CO2RR. A comprehensive calculation of the Gibbs free energy change for elementary reactions was conducted to obtain the limiting potential of all C1 products, thereby elucidating the catalytic activity of these materials. Furthermore, the selectivity between CO2RR and the competing HER on the catalysts was considered by comparing the limiting potentials of the two reactions. To investigate the origin of catalytic activity, the electronic band structures of pristine C x N3 and Ru-C x N3 were analyzed to understand the regulatory effect of Ru on C x N3. Moreover, linear relationships between the Gibbs free energy change of *OCHO and the catalyst d band center, as well as the integrated crystal orbital Hamiltonian population of Ru-O, indicate that as the C/N-ratio of C x N3 increases, the adsorption of *OCHO weakens, leading to enhanced catalytic activity. 2 Computational methods In this work, all the relevant calculations were executed using a spin-unrestricted DFT methods implemented by the DMol3 module in the Materials Studio software [41,42]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional of the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) was utilized to represent the exchange and correlation model. To describe the atomic orbitals, the double numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis set was employed [43]. The convergence tolerance for energy change, max force, and max displacement were 1 × 10−5 Ha (1 Ha = 27.2114 eV), 2 × 10−3 Ha Å−1, and 5 × 10−3 Å, respectively. To avoid the interactions between periodic images, a vacuum layer with a thickness of 30 Å was added. The Brillouin-zone was sampled using a 3 × 3 × 1 k-point mesh. Additionally, the parameters used for the calculation of electronic structure were consistent with those used for structure optimization. The electronic structure analysis methods considered in this work include PDOS, the COHP, the deformation charge density, and the Hirshfeld charge. It is important to note that the Van der Waals (vdW) interactions can influence the adsorption of CO2 molecule, thereby having a certain effect on the catalytic activity. However, in order to compare the results with other similar works, we ignore them in this work. The stability of M-C x N3 (x = 7, 10, 13, 19) is evaluated through the Formation energy (E f), and it is defined as: (1) E f = E M − CxN 3 − E CxN 3 − E M where E M-C x N3 indicates the total energy of single metal atoms doped into C x N3, E C x N3 is the energy of C x N3, E M represents metal atom in bulk structure. The electrochemical stability of M-C x N3 is evaluated by the dissolution potential (U diss) of metal atom is calculated using the following equation [44]: (2) U d i s s = U ∘ d i s s ( m e t a l , b u l k ) − E f / e N e where U°diss(metal, bulk) is the standard dissolution potential of metal in bulk phase, N e is denoted the number of electrons involved during dissolution. The Adsorption energy (E ads) is calculated by the under formula: (3) E ads = E total − E spei ces − E M − CxN 3 where E total is the total energy of M-C x N3 binding with adsorbed species, E speices is the energy of adsorbed species. The computational hydrogen electrode method (CHE) model by Nørskov et al. was used for calculating the Gibbs free energy [45]. The calculation of Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) is using the following formula: (4) Δ G = Δ E + Δ Z P E + ∫ C P d T − T Δ S in which ΔE is the difference of energy changes by DFT calculation results, ΔZPE, ΔS, and ∫ C P d T are the zero-point energy correction, entropy change, and the enthalpic (heat capacity) corrections, respectively. T is the temperature (298.15 K). The limiting potential (U L) is calculated by following equation: (5) U L = − Δ G m a x / e where ΔG max is the ΔG of the potential determining step (PDS). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and stability of catalyst The C7N3, C10N3, C1 3N3, and C19N3 monolayers can be constructed based on RG2 method [46]. Initially, a six-membered ring was removed from a graphene supercell to create a hole, and the C atoms situated on the edge of the hole were subsequently replaced by N atoms, as illustrated in Fig. S1. The 4-fold cell of C x N3 (C8 x N24, the 2 × 2 supercell) are optimized and presented in Fig. 1a –d. There is an intrinsic central cavity that single metal atom can be securely anchored and form SACs. n this study, Ru, Rh, and Pd were chosen for doping into C x N3, resulting in M-C x N3 (M = Ru, Rh, Pd; x = 7, 10, 13, 19). After structural optimization, the metal atoms in all 12 catalysts were found to be surrounded by two N atoms, as depicted in Fig. S2. It is noteworthy that constructional stability is a prerequisite for screening promising catalysts and efficiently catalyzing CO2RR. The formation energy (E f) and dissolution potential (U diss) were calculated to evaluate the stability of M-C x N3, as shown in Fig. 2a . Generally, a negative E f value indicates thermodynamic stability, while a positive U diss value suggests electrochemical stability. A catalyst is considered stable when it meets both criteria simultaneously. The E f values of M-C x N3 were found to range from −2.54 to −6.85 eV, with U diss values ranging from 1.73 to 4.03 V, demonstrating excellent stability across all M-C x N3 catalysts. All E f and U diss values of M-C x N3 are summarized in the Table S1. Notably, the stability of M-C x N3 increases with rising C/N-ratio. To further investigate the thermodynamic stability of the catalysts, first-principles molecular dynamics simulations were performed on Ru-C7N3, Rh-C7N3, and Pd-C7N3 as examples. These simulations were conducted at 500 K for 5 ps. As illustrated in Fig. 2b–d, despite being the catalysts with relatively weak stability under the E f and U diss criteria, Ru-C7N3, Rh-C7N3, and Pd-C7N3 maintained extremely small energy fluctuations throughout the simulation process. Moreover, their structures did not exhibit significant deformation, further confirming their excellent stability. 3.2 CO2 adsorption The adsorption of CO2 on the catalyst's active site is a critical focus, as it initiates the overall electrocatalytic reaction. Due to the chemical inertness of CO2 molecules, the degree of activation significantly influences subsequent CO2RR processes. An investigation of CO2 adsorption on M-C x N3 is conducted, as illustrated in Fig. 3 and Fig. S3. The optimized C-terminal adsorption of *CO2 is considered in Fig. 3, the optimized O-terminal adsorption of *CO2 is considered in Fig. S3. In the Fig. 3, two distinct adsorption configurations are observed: chemisorption and physisorption. In chemisorption, both O and C atoms of CO2 exhibit significant interaction with Ru and Rh active sites (Fig. 3a–b). Conversely, physisorption is observed with Pd active sites, which demonstrate minimal adsorption of CO2 molecules (Fig. 3c). The adsorption energy (E ads) of *CO2 is calculated for various structures. For Ru-C x N3 (x = 7, 10, 13, 19), the E ads values are determined to be −0.36, −0.41, −0.41, and −0.53 eV, respectively. Correspondingly, the bond angles (∠O − C − O) of *CO2 on Ru-C x N3 are measured at 145.19°, 144.58°, 144.45°, and 143.55° Hirshfeld charge analysis reveals electron transfers from Ru-C x N3 to *CO2 of 0.26, 0.29, 0.31, and 0.32 |e|. Calculation results for the remaining catalysts are summarized in Table S2. These findings indicate that more negative E ads values of *CO2 correlate with smaller ∠O − C − O and increased electron transfer from catalyst to *CO2. Notably, Ru-C19N3 demonstrates a superior ability to capture and activate CO2 molecules, suggesting its potential as a candidate for catalyzing CO2RR. However, the O-terminal adsorption of *CO2 in the Fig. S3 shows that the CO2 molecule does not have no change in bond angles. Therefore, the O-terminal does not allow the CO2 molecule to be effectively activated by the catalysts. To elucidate the activation properties of *CO2 on catalysts, partial density of state (PDOS) calculations is performed to analyze the interaction between CO2 molecules and the active sites of catalysts (Fig. 4 and Fig. S4). For Ru- and Rh-C x N3, overlaps between the 3d orbitals of Ru and Rh and the 2p orbitals of *CO2 are observed at the Fermi level (Fig. 4a–d). This overlap indicates robust interaction between *CO2 and Ru and Rh atoms. In contrast, orbital overlap between the 2p of *CO2 and 3d of Pd is not clearly discernible (Fig. 4e and F). Furthermore, the PDOS of M-C x N3 are also calculated and shown in Fig. S5. The enhanced energy level splitting near the Fermi level of Ru and Rh 3d can be observed, a characteristic feature of SACs that significantly enhances the activation of CO2 molecules [47]. These results align with the aforementioned electron transfer study. Significantly greater charge transfer is observed from Ru and Rh to *CO2 compared to Pd, demonstrating that single Ru and Rh atoms function as efficient active centers and can promote further hydrogenation. Due to insufficient activation of *CO2 on Pd-C x N3 (x = 7, 10, 13, 19), these catalysts are excluded from further investigation of the CO2RR mechanism. 3.3 Reaction mechanism and catalytic activity CO2 can be converted into multiple products through CO2RR. This process involves the formation of common products such as carbon monoxide (CO), formic acid (HCOOH), methanol (CH3OH), and methane (CH4) through two, six, and eight electron transfers, respectively. Additionally, CO2RR can produce C–C coupling products, including ethylene (C2H4) and ethanol (C2H5OH) [48]. However, due to the single active site of SACs, C–C coupling is not feasible [49]. Therefore, this study focuses on the reaction pathway of C1 products. The possible elementary reaction pathways are plotted in Fig. 5 . 3.3.1 CO2RR reaction pathways to CO on catalysts The Gibbs free energy of intermediates on Ru- and Rh-C x N3 catalysts has been calculated. The most favorable reaction path for each C1 product has been determined, and the Gibbs free energy diagrams for CO2RR on these catalysts are presented in Fig. 6 . The reaction pathway for CO2 conversion to CO follows the sequence: * + CO2 → *COOH → *CO → * + CO. In the initial protonation step, the O atom of * CO2 is attacked by a proton-electron pair (H + + e −), forming the *COOH intermediate. Subsequently, *COOH undergoes further hydrogenation to form *CO. Finally, the *CO intermediate desorbs from the active site, resulting in the CO product. For Ru-C x N3 catalysts, both the first and second protonation steps are spontaneous processes. In contrast, the formation of *COOH on Rh-C x N3 is non-spontaneous. However, the desorption of *CO is significantly challenging on both Ru- and Rh-C x N3 catalysts. This difficulty in *CO desorption determines the poor catalytic activity of these catalysts for CO2RR to generate CO, with U L values ranging from −1.54 to −2.78 V. 3.3.2 CO2RR reaction pathways to HCOOH on catalysts For Ru-C x N3, the reaction pathway of generate HCOOH product is * + CO2 → *OCHO → *HCOOH → * + HCOOH and PDS is * + CO2 → *OCHO. However, the U L values are different, they are −0.36, −0.33, −0.30, and −0.18 V for Ru-C7N3, Ru-C10N3, Ru-C1 3N3, and Ru-C19N3, respectively. In the case of Rh-C x N3 catalysts, the reaction pathway is * + CO2 → *COOH → *HCOOH → * + HCOOH, as illustrated in Fig. 6e–h. The common PDS for Rh-C7N3, Rh-C10N3, and Rh-C1 3N3 is * + CO2 → *COOH, with U L values of −0.36, −0.49, and −0.55 V, respectively. For Rh-C19N3, the PDS of CO2RR is *COOH → *HCOOH, with a U L value of −0.35 V. This is due to the higher Gibbs free energy value of ΔG*HCOOH compared to ΔG*COOH (0.35 vs. 0.26 eV). 3.3.3 CO2RR reaction pathways to CH3OH on catalysts The conversion of CO2 into CH3OH on Ru-C x N3 catalysts follows diverse favorable reaction pathways. For Ru-C7N3, the initial protonation step involves the formation of *OCHO, which is subsequently hydrogenated to *HCOOH. A proton-electron pair then attacks the O atom of *HCOOH, forming the *OCH2OH intermediate. Further protonation of *OCH2OH leads to the formation of *O intermediate and the release of CH3OH. Continuous protonation of *O results in the formation of *H2O intermediate. The most favorable reaction pathway on Ru-C7N3 is thus: * + CO2 → *OCHO → *HCOOH → *OCH2OH → *O + CH3OH → *OH → *H2O → H2O. The PDS is *OH → *H2O with a U L value of −0.55 V. Ru-C10N3, Ru-C1 3N3, and Ru-C19N3 share a common favorable reaction pathway: * + CO2 → *OCHO → *HCOOH → *OCH2OH → *CH2O + H2O → *CH3O → *CH3OH → * + CH3OH. For Ru-C1 3N3 and Ru-C19N3, *CH3O → *CH3OH is the common PDS with U L values of −0.41 V and −0.70 V, respectively. The PDS for Ru-C10N3 is * + CO2 → *COOH with a U L value of −0.33 V. Regarding Rh-C x N3 catalysts, Rh-C7N3 and Rh-C10N3 follow the pathway: * + CO2 → *COOH → *HCOOH → *OCH2OH → *O + CH3OH → *OH → *H2O → H2O. Their respective PDS are *OCH2OH → *O + CH3OH and *HCOOH → *OCH2OH, with corresponding U L values of −0.46 and −0.61 V. Rh-C1 3N3 follows a distinct path for CH3OH production: * + CO2 → *COOH → *HCOOH → *CHO + H2O → *CHOH → *CH2OH → *CH3OH → * + CH3OH. The PDS for Rh-C1 3N3 is *CHOH → *CH2OH with a U L value of −0.59 V. The favorable reaction pathway for Rh-C19N3 is: * + CO2 → *COOH → *HCOOH → *OCH2OH → *CH2O + H2O → *CH2OH → *CH3OH → * + CH3OH. The PDS for Rh-C19N3 is *OCH2OH → *CH2O + H2O with a U L value of −0.58 V. 3.3.4 CO2RR reaction pathways to CH4 on catalysts All Ru-C x N3 (x = 7, 10, 13, 19) catalysts follow an identical reaction pathway for CO2 conversion to CH4: * + CO2 → *OCHO → *HCOOH → *OCH2OH → *CH2O + H2O →*CH3O → *O + CH4 → *OH → *H2O → * + H2O. The common PDS is *O → *OH, with varying catalytic activities reflected in U L values of −0.55, −0.81, −0.99, and −0.40 V, respectively. Rh-C7N3 and Rh-C10N3 share a favorable reaction pathway: * + CO2 → *COOH → *HCOOH → *OCH2OH → *CH2O + H2O → *CH3O → *O + CH4 → *OH → *H2O → * + H2O. The PDS is *CH2O + H2O → *CH3O with U L values of −0.83 and −0.91 V, respectively. The reaction pathway for CH4 production on Rh-C1 3N3 is: * + CO2 → *COOH → *HCOOH → *CHO + H2O → *CHOH → *CH2OH → *CH2 + H2O → *CH3 → *CH4 → * + CH4. The U L value for Rh-C1 3N3 is −0.88 V. For Rh-C19N3, the reaction pathway is: * + CO2 → *COOH → *HCOOH → *OCH2OH → *CH2O + H2O → *CH2OH → *CH2 + H2O → *CH3 → *CH4 → * + CH4. The PDS is *CH2OH → *CH2 + H2O with a U L value of −0.95 V. It is generally known that a low negative U L value indicates superior CO2RR catalytic activity. Table 1 summarizes the lowest U L values for Ru- and Rh-C x N3 catalysts in this study and comparable catalysts previously reported for C1 products. All catalysts exhibit excellent selectivity and activity for HCOOH production, surpassing the performance of previously reported catalysts such as Ru@C3N4 (−0.61 V), Rh-C3N (−0.57 V), Ru@C2N (−0.56 V), and Rh@C2N (−0.95 V) [50–52]. 3.3.5 Side reaction and solvation effect The presence of the HER as a side reaction to CO2RR significantly impairs the efficiency and selectivity of CO2RR. The Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔG *H) is widely regarded as the primary descriptor for evaluating HER catalytic activity. A ΔG *H value closer to zero indicates superior HER catalytic performance [53]. Consequently, the ΔG *H values of Ru- and Rh-C x N3 (x = 7, 10, 13, 19) were calculated and are presented in Fig. 7a . To assess the competition between CO2RR and HER, the limiting potential differences (U L(CO2RR) – U L(HER)) were computed and are illustrated in Fig. 7b. A positive value of limiting potential difference signifies the prioritization of CO2RR over HER for the corresponding catalysts. For Ru-C x N3, the inferior catalytic activity for CO2 to CO conversion results in substantial negative values of U L(CO) – U L(HER). However, the positive values of U L(HCOOH) – U L(HER) suggest that HCOOH is an ideal product for CO2RR on Ru-C x N3. Furthermore, with the exception of Ru-C19N3, the positive values of U L(CH3OH) – U L(HER) indicate higher selectivity for CO2RR compared to HER. Regarding CH4 production, CO2RR is predominant on Ru-C7N3 and Ru-C19N3 due to the positive U L(CH4) – U L(HER) values (0.04 and 0.24 V, respectively). Unfortunately, Rh-C x N3 exhibits superior catalytic selectivity for HER over CO2RR due to the favorable adsorption of *H on active sites, making it unsuitable as an efficient CO2RR catalyst. In order to investigate the solvation effect on Ru-C x N3 for CO2RR, an implicit solvation model is constructed, and the dielectric constant is set to 78.54 in order to simulate the water environment. The results of the comparative analysis conducted at the vacuum and implicit solvation models are presented in the Fig. S6. It can be found that the Ru-C x N3 still maintains the same PDS as in a vacuum condition, and the average U L difference is less than 0.10 V. Therefore, the solvation effect, as considered in this study, has a negligible impact on the catalytic performance of the screened catalysts. 3.4 Origin of catalytic activity To elucidate the regulatory effect of the electronic structure of pristine C x N3 upon doping with a single Ru atom and to investigate its impact on the electrocatalytic performance of C x N3, the electronic band structures and density of states (DOS) of both pristine C x N3 and Ru-C x N3 were calculated. The results are presented in Fig. S7 and S8. The introduction of a single Ru atom is observed to decrease the bandgap energies of all pristine C x N3 structures. This reduction in bandgap energy indicates an improvement in the overall conductivity of the catalyst following Ru atom doping into pristine C x N3. The enhanced catalyst conductivity is expected to facilitate electron transfer during the CO2RR process. To further investigate the exceptional catalytic activity of Ru-C x N3 (x = 7, 10, 13, 19) in converting CO2 to HCOOH, *OCHO is identified as the key intermediate due to the shared PDS: * + CO2 → *OCHO. The ΔG *OCHO value is equivalent to the U L, thereby establishing ΔG *OCHO as an activity descriptor. The d band center (ε d) is commonly employed to characterize the electronic properties of materials. A distinct linear relationship between ε d and ΔG *OCHO on Ru-C x N3 is observed, with an R² value of 0.93, as illustrated in Fig. 8 (a). According to d band center theory, a d band center closer to the Fermi level results in stronger interactions between the catalyst and intermediates [54]. The ε d values demonstrate that as the C/N ratio increases, ε d shifts further from the Fermi level. This shift weakens the adsorption strength of the key intermediate and promotes HCOOH desorption from the catalysts. In comparison to Ru-C x N3 (x = 7, 10, 13) (d band energies: −0.62, −0.92, and −1.05 eV), the antibonding states of the *OCHO intermediate are positioned at lower energies on Ru-C19N3 (−1.51 eV), with higher occupancy by additional electrons [55]. The ε d values also exhibit good linear relationship with the x value of Ru-C x N3 as shown in Fig. 8b. The crystal orbital Hamiltonian population (COHP) for the Ru atom and O atom of the *OCHO intermediate on Ru-C x N3 is calculated. The ICOHP value is utilized to quantitatively describe the binding strength. A linear relationship between ICOHP values of Ru-C x N3 and ΔG *OCHO is observed, as shown in Fig. 8 (b). More negative ICOHP values indicate stronger interactions between Ru and O atoms. This linear relationship reveals that more negative ICOHP values of Ru-C x N3 correspond to greater binding strength between Ru and O atoms, resulting in decreased catalytic activation for CO2RR. In summary, the enhancement of catalyst conductivity through Ru atom doping is initially examined. Subsequently, the Gibbs free energy change of the key intermediate *OCHO is considered as an activity descriptor. The connections between ε d, ICOHP, and ΔG *OCHO are explored, demonstrating that a higher C/N ratio modulates the adsorption of the key intermediate OCHO, thereby improving the catalytic activation of Ru-C x N3. 4 Conclusion In this study, DFT methods are used to investigate the catalytic performance of M-C x N3 (M = Ru, Rh, Pd; x = 7, 10, 13, 19) for CO2RR. The thermodynamic and electrochemical stability of M-C x N3 were initially assessed through the calculation of E f and U diss. The results demonstrate the structural stability of these catalysts. Furthermore, the dynamic stability was verified using first principles molecular dynamics simulations at 500 K, with Ru-, Rh-, and Pd-C7N3 serving as exemplars. Subsequently, the adsorption and activation behavior of CO2 on the catalyst active sites were scrutinized. Analyses of adsorption energy (E ads), bond angle, charge transfer, and PDOS of *CO2 on catalysts reveal that Ru-C x N3 and Rh-C x N3 exhibit chemisorption of the CO2 molecule. However, Pd-C x N3 demonstrated inadequate CO2 molecule activation and was consequently excluded from further CO2RR mechanism studies. A comprehensive calculation of the Gibbs free energy change for each elementary reaction was conducted, and the limiting potential for all C1 products was determined to unveil the catalytic activity of Ru-C x N3 and Rh-C x N3. Concurrently, the competitive selectivity between CO2RR and HER on these catalysts was examined by calculating U L(CO2RR) – U L(HER). Despite Rh-C x N3 exhibiting remarkable activity for catalyzing CO2RR to produce HCOOH, its superior activity for HER diminishes its potential as a promising CO2RR electrocatalyst. Ru-C x N3 catalysts demonstrated commendable catalytic activity and selectivity for HCOOH production. The optimal reaction pathway was identified as: * + CO2 → *OCHO → *HCOOH → * + HCOOH, with the PDS being * + CO2 → *OCHO (U L = −0.36, −0.33, −0.30, and −0.18 V, respectively). To explore the origin of catalytic activity, electronic band structures of pristine C x N3 and Ru-C x N3 were calculated to analyze the regulatory effect of Ru on C x N3. The introduction of a single Ru atom resulted in decreased bandgap energies for all pristine C x N3 materials, indicating improved electron transfer within the pristine material. The Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) of the key intermediate *OCHO was considered as a simple activity descriptor due to its equivalence to U L. Linear relationships between ΔG *OCHO and catalyst ε d, as well as the ICOHP of Ru-O, indicate an intrinsic connection between C x N3 C/N-ratio and catalyst activity. This connection is achieved by modulating the catalyst's adsorption capacity for the key reaction intermediate. In conclusion, this computational study provides comprehensive guidance and insights for the experimental synthesis and exploration of CO2RR electrocatalysts' catalytic performance. The findings elucidate the fundamental principles governing the activity and selectivity of M-C x N3 catalysts, paving the way for the rational design of efficient CO2RR electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: The development of efficient catalysts for the electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) has emerged as a primary focus in contemporary research. In this study, a series of single-atom catalysts are constructed by doping Ru, Rh, and Pd into C x N3 (x = 7, 10, 13, 19), denoted as M-C x N3. Density functional theory (DFT) methods are employed to systematically investigate the CO2RR catalytic activity and mechanism on M-C x N3. The catalysts are found to exhibit thermodynamic, electrochemical, and dynamic stability, as evidenced by formation energy calculations, dissolution potential assessments, and first principles molecular dynamics simulations. Gibbs free energy calculations reveal that Ru-C x N3 demonstrates exceptional catalytic selectivity towards HCOOH production, with optimal catalytic activity observed at low limiting potentials (x = 7: –0.36 V, x = 10: –0.33 V, x = 13: –0.30 V, and x = 19: –0.18 V). Furthermore, Ru-C x N3 effectively suppresses the competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). Linear relationships between the Gibbs free energy change of the key intermediate *OCHO and the catalyst d band center, as well as the integration crystal orbital Hamiltonian population (ICOHP), indicate that Ru doping and higher C/N-ratios in C x N3 enhance catalytic performance for CO2RR. This computational study provides comprehensive guidance and insights for the experimental synthesis and exploration of CO2RR electrocatalysts.
